newsitem.title: CHINA: China raises crude price by 86.8 yuan per T.
newsitem.headline: China raises crude price by 86.8 yuan per T.

text.p: China raised the price of its domestic crude oil by 86.8 yuan per tonne effective from December 25 last year, officials said on Friday.

The China National Petroleum Corp raised the price at which it sells its crude to Sinopec as part of its drive to end preferential prices and bring prices into line with market levels, an official of Shanghai Petrochemical said by telephone.
An official at Sinopec said the price increase went into effect from December 25 and was 86.8 yuan per tonne. He refused to give the current price.
The Hong Kong Economic Journal said on Friday the previous price for crude from Daqing was 1,020 yuan per tonne and from Shengli was 893 yuan per tonne.

Shanghai Petrochemical was the company most affected by the price increase since it relies mainly on domestic crude, while other major petrochemical firms depend more on imports, the Shanghai official said.
However, a decision to raise the price of diesel and fuel oil had helped to offset the effect of the crude price hike on Shanghai Petrochemical's production costs, he said.
